title: 109_hr2008
content: The "Public Private Vocational Partnership Act of 2005" allows for donations to secondary schools and community colleges for vocational education purposes under section 45J of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Public Private Vocational Partnership Act of 2005" allows corporations to claim a vocational education donation credit under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit includes 90% of the fair market value of qualified property donations and intern credit amounts. There are limitations on the credit, with a maximum of $50,000 for property donations and $100 per month for each qualified intern. The taxpayer can claim a credit for intern expenses, with a maximum of $6,000 per intern. Qualified property donations refer to charitable contributions of tangible personal property to educational organizations in the US for educational purposes. The taxpayer can claim a credit for intern expenses, with a maximum of $6,000 per intern. Qualified property donations must meet specific criteria, including not being exchanged for money or other services, fitting into the donee's education plan, and meeting minimum functionality standards for educational purposes. A qualified intern is a full-time student in a secondary school or community college. A qualified intern for the taxpayer's credit must be a full-time student in a secondary school or community college, employed for up to 20 hours per week as part of an approved vocational education course. Secondary school refers to a school offering vocational education, while a community college is a regionally accredited institution providing a 2-year program leading to an associate degree. The text discusses the aggregation rule for determining a single employer under specific sections and the coordination with Section 170(b) to reduce the limitation for taxable years. Additionally, it mentions the amendment to the general business credit section by adding a new paragraph. The text introduces a new paragraph regarding vocational education donation credits for corporations, along with amendments to Section 280C and a conforming amendment to the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004 for donations to secondary schools and community colleges for vocational education purposes.
